Home / Diseases / Shoulder
Shoulder Nerve Disorder

Suprascapular Neuropathy

A cause of deep shoulder pain and weakness often missed or misdiagnosed. Common in overhead athletes and can be caused by ganglion cysts .

Medically Reviewed

Dr. Carlos Rivero Siri
Specialist in Orthopaedics & Shoulder Surgery
Updated: 25 December 2024

Key Points ⏱ 10 min read

Suprascapular neuropathy causes deep, diffuse shoulder pain and weakness in abduction/external rotation. Often caused by ganglion cysts or repetitive overhead activities. Clinical examination is key – isolated motor weakness without sensory loss points to diagnosis. Arthroscopic decompression offers excellent outcomes when surgery is needed.

✓ 92-98% return to sport after surgery
✓ 3–6 months conservative if no cyst/atrophy/edema
✓ 3-8 months return to competition (post-surgery)
📑 Contents
1 Etiology & Pathology 2 Symptoms 3 Diagnosis 4 Treatment 5 Sick Leave 6 Return to Sport 💡 Expert Perspective ? FAQ 📚 References

🔬 Nerve Anatomy

Origin

C5–C6 (variable C4 contribution).

Course

Passes through the suprascapular notch (under the superior transverse scapular ligament) → supraspinous fossa → around scapular spine via spinoglenoid notch → infraspinous fossa.

Motor Innervation

  • •M. supraspinatus
  • •M. infraspinatus

Sensory Innervation

  • •Glenohumeral joint
  • •AC joint
  • •Subacromial bursa
  • •Coracoclavicular & coracohumeral ligaments

No regular skin innervation.

💡 Clinical Relevance

Proximal entrapment (suprascapular notch): affects both muscles + sensory.
Distal entrapment (spinoglenoid notch): spares supraspinatus but may cause posterior shoulder pain via capsular innervation.

🟠 Paralabral Ganglion Cysts

Ganglion Cysts as a Cause

Paralabral ganglion cysts can cause suprascapular neuropathy by compressing the nerve. These cysts typically arise from labral tears and compress the nerve at the spinoglenoid notch. Note: Studies reporting cysts as the most common cause may reflect selection bias—patients often undergo MRI first, which detects cysts. Clinicians who perform careful clinical examination will identify many cases without cysts.

• Often associated with posterosuperior labral tears
• Compress nerve at spinoglenoid notch
• Cause isolated infraspinatus atrophy
Treatment

Labral repair alone – cysts resolve spontaneously. Excellent return to sport rates.

1 Etiology & Pathology

Suprascapular neuropathy is caused by compression or traction of the suprascapular nerve along its course from the brachial plexus to the rotator cuff muscles .

Primary (Dynamic) Causes

  • • Repetitive overhead activities
  • • Volleyball, baseball, swimming
  • • Overhead laborers
  • • Nerve stretch and microtrauma

Secondary (Structural) Causes

  • • Paralabral ganglion cysts
  • • Massive rotator cuff tears
  • • Fractures (scapular neck)
  • • Tumors

Anatomical Predisposition

Certain anatomical variations increase the risk of nerve entrapment :

⚠ Narrow suprascapular notch
⚠ Ossified superior transverse scapular ligament (~12%)
⚠ Type III notch (small, V-shaped)
⚠ Hypertrophied ligament

2 Symptoms & Clinical Presentation

Patients typically present with insidious onset of deep, diffuse shoulder pain and progressive weakness .

Pain Character

Deep, dull, and diffuse. Posterior and lateral shoulder.

Radiation

Most commonly radiates to the muscles innervated by the suprascapular nerve (supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles). Sometimes pain in the infraclavicular region.

Weakness

Abduction and external rotation weakness.

Muscle Atrophy

Visible muscle wasting is a key clinical sign. The pattern of atrophy depends on the site of nerve compression:

  • • Suprascapular notch: Both supraspinatus AND infraspinatus weakness/atrophy
  • • Spinoglenoid notch: Isolated infraspinatus weakness/atrophy (typical for cysts)

💡 Diagnostic implication: Combined weakness of both supraspinatus and infraspinatus effectively rules out a paralabral ganglion cyst – cysts only affect the inferior branch at the spinoglenoid notch (→ isolated infraspinatus involvement). MRI may be unnecessary in these cases.

⚠ Often Misdiagnosed

Suprascapular neuropathy is frequently mistaken for rotator cuff disease, cervical radiculopathy, or non-specific shoulder pain. A high index of suspicion is needed, especially in overhead athletes with weakness out of proportion to pain .

3 Diagnosis

Diagnosis relies on clinical examination, electrodiagnostic studies, and imaging .

Clinical Examination

The key diagnostic finding is pain-free weakness in the muscles innervated by the suprascapular nerve. Strength testing of supraspinatus or infraspinatus is not meaningful if it provokes pain, as the patient cannot resist adequately when in pain.

Supraspinatus Strength

Test abduction strength in a pain-free range. Weakness indicates suprascapular notch entrapment affecting the superior branch.

Infraspinatus Strength

Test external rotation strength in a pain-free position. Weakness indicates involvement of the inferior branch (spinoglenoid notch or more proximal).

MRI - Structural Assessment

MRI is the preferred imaging modality to identify the cause and assess muscle involvement :

  • •Ganglion cysts and space-occupying lesions
  • •Muscle edema on T2/STIR (early sign of denervation – more sensitive than EMG)
  • •Fatty infiltration and atrophy (chronic)
  • •Associated labral pathology

⭐ EMG/NCV - Gold Standard (in Literature)

Electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction velocity (NCV) studies are described in the literature as the gold standard for confirming diagnosis and localizing the exact site of nerve lesion . EMG can differentiate between suprascapular notch and spinoglenoid notch compression based on the pattern of muscle involvement.

⚠ Clinical consideration: The suprascapular nerve typically lacks a cutaneous sensory branch (although rare anatomical variations exist), making diagnosis primarily clinical. When isolated motor weakness is present, waiting for EMG confirmation risks permanent muscle damage. Early intervention may be more important than confirmatory testing.

4 Treatment Options

Treatment depends on the underlying cause. Conservative management is appropriate for dynamic entrapment without space-occupying lesions .

Conservative Treatment

A 3–6 month trial of conservative management may be considered when :

  • ✓No ganglion cyst or space-occupying lesion
  • ✓No atrophy of rotator cuff muscles
  • ✓No muscle edema or fatty infiltration on MRI/ultrasound
  • ✓No signs of extensive nerve damage

Treatment components:

✓
Activity modification: Avoid overhead movements and provocative activities
✓
NSAIDs: For pain and inflammation control
✓
Physical therapy: Periscapular strengthening and flexibility
✓
Scapular mechanics: Optimize scapulothoracic rhythm

Surgical Treatment

Surgery is indicated for :

  • •Space-occupying lesions (ganglion cysts, tumors)
  • •Severe or progressive muscle atrophy
  • •Failure of 6-month conservative trial

Arthroscopic Decompression – Modern Gold Standard

Arthroscopic nerve release offers better visualization, lower morbidity, and faster recovery compared to open approaches . The procedure involves release of the transverse scapular ligament at the suprascapular notch. When a paralabral cyst is present at the spinoglenoid notch, labral repair alone is sufficient – the cyst resolves spontaneously.

5 Sick Leave & Return to Work

Recovery timelines after surgical intervention vary based on the type of work .

Sedentary / Office Work

Return to normal daily activities and desk work. Typically within 1 week (range: 0–3 weeks)

0–3 weeks

Light to Moderate Manual Labor

Light manual work without heavy lifting. Active movements within painless range

2–6 weeks

Heavy Manual Labor

Return to heavy lifting when strength is normalized. Muscle strengthening programs begin at 6–8 weeks postop

6–12 weeks

6 Return to Sport (RTS)

Return to sport outcomes after suprascapular nerve decompression are excellent .

Rehabilitation Protocol

1
Week 0–2: Passive motion, Codman's exercises, isometric exercises
2
Week 4–8: Strengthening programs begin (4 weeks if isolated decompression, 6 weeks if labral repair also performed)
3
Month 3–8: Sport-specific training and return to competition

Return to Training

4–8 weeks

Non-contact, sport-specific activities

Return to Competition

3–8 months

Full contact, competitive play

✓ Outstanding Outcomes

92–98%

Return to sport

88–96%

Return to previous level

~50%

Complete muscle recovery

Note: Despite excellent functional outcomes, only about 50% of patients show complete recovery of infraspinatus muscle volume. However, this typically does not significantly impact sports performance.

Conservative Treatment RTS

In cases of dynamic primary compression treated conservatively, athletes may return to competition within 3 months if symptoms resolve with activity modification and physical therapy.

Contents

1 Etiology & Pathology 2 Symptoms 3 Diagnosis 4 Treatment 5 Sick Leave 6 Return to Sport 💡 Expert Perspective ? FAQ 📚 References

At-Risk Athletes

Dynamic entrapment from repetitive overhead activities is common in certain sports .

🏐 Volleyball – serving & spiking
⚾ Baseball – pitching
🎾 Tennis – serving
🏊 Swimming – overhead strokes

Clinical Pearl

"Always think of suprascapular neuropathy in overhead athletes with external rotation weakness and posterior shoulder pain – especially if there's visible infraspinatus atrophy."

Clinical pearl: Combined weakness of both muscles typically indicates proximal entrapment (suprascapular notch), not a cyst.

Perform ultrasound examination to exclude large cysts near the transverse ligament or spinoglenoid region. MRI is often unnecessary when combined weakness is present.

🔴 Differential Diagnosis

Consider these conditions:

• Massive rotator cuff tears
• Cervical radiculopathy (C5-C6)
• Parsonage-Turner syndrome

⚠️ Parsonage-Turner: If weakness extends beyond supraspinatus/infraspinatus, consider neuralgic amyotrophy – refer to neurologist, not surgical intervention.

Expert Perspective

My approach to suprascapular nerve entrapment

At Södermalms Ortopedi, we frequently see patients with suspected suprascapular nerve entrapment. Typical symptoms include deep shoulder pain, weakness in external rotation (infraspinatus) and/or abduction (supraspinatus), sometimes with visible atrophy.

My Diagnostic Approach

My management is primarily based on a thorough clinical examination. After completing a full neurological assessment (to exclude axillary nerve involvement, accessory nerve pathology, or cervical radiculopathy), the key clinical finding of isolated weakness in supraspinatus and/or infraspinatus carries the most weight for both diagnosis and surgical indication.

💤

A Question I Always Ask

"Have you recently changed your sleeping position? Does your partner notice you sleeping with your arm over or under your head?"

In my clinical experience, I've seen several cases of suprascapular nerve entrapment triggered by sleeping with the arm elevated above or beneath the head. This sustained traction on the nerve can cause symptoms that often resolve simply by correcting the sleeping position. Not described in literature – but worth asking about, as it may spare the patient unnecessary investigations or surgery.

EMG/Nerve Conduction Studies

I rarely use electrophysiology routinely for this diagnosis. The test is often normal in mild to moderate weakness (as early involvement is primarily demyelination without axonal loss). Positive findings are usually only seen with pronounced weakness or atrophy. Literature shows that normal electrophysiology does not exclude clinically relevant entrapment, and it rarely changes my management.

MRI

MRI is valuable in selected cases, particularly when I need to:

  • •Exclude Parsonage-Turner syndrome (neuralgic amyotrophy)
  • •Identify compressive causes like ganglion cysts
  • •Assess muscle edema (T2-hyperintensity) – more sensitive than EMG for early involvement

💡 Clinical Pearl

Perform ultrasound examination to exclude large cysts near the transverse ligament or spinoglenoid region. MRI is often unnecessary when combined weakness is present.

Surgical Indication & Timing

When isolated weakness in supraspinatus and/or infraspinatus is confirmed, I typically recommend early arthroscopic decompression (release of the transverse scapular ligament at the suprascapular notch). If a paralabral cyst is present, I perform labral repair only – the cyst resolves spontaneously without direct decompression. The procedure is minimally invasive, usually takes me 5–15 minutes, and is performed as outpatient surgery.

The rationale for early surgery is to avoid the risk of irreversible axonal damage and permanent weakness. Waiting for clearer EMG findings or progressive atrophy is unnecessary when the procedure is so straightforward and safe.

Summary

  • 1. Primary diagnosis: Clinical examination (isolated weakness)
  • 2. Selective investigations: MRI when needed for differential diagnosis or identifying compressive causes; electrophysiology rarely indicated
  • 3. Treatment: Early arthroscopic release for motor involvement – excellent prognosis with >90–95% improvement in pain and strength

Dr. Carlos Rivero Siri

Specialist in Orthopaedics & Shoulder Surgery

Frequently Asked Questions

What causes suprascapular neuropathy?
Compression or traction of the nerve from various causes including ganglion cysts, repetitive overhead activities, massive rotator cuff tears, or anatomical variations .
How is it diagnosed?
EMG/NCV studies are the gold standard for confirming diagnosis. MRI identifies structural causes like cysts and assesses muscle involvement .
When is surgery needed?
Surgery is indicated for space-occupying lesions (cysts), severe atrophy, or failure of 3–6 months of conservative treatment .
Will my muscle recover?
While 92-98% regain normal function, only ~50% show complete muscle volume recovery. However, this usually doesn't affect daily function or sports performance .
How long until I can return to sports?
Most athletes return to competition within 3-8 months after surgery. With conservative treatment for dynamic compression, return can occur within 3 months. 92-98% return to sport, with 88-96% reaching their previous performance level .
